key_title: Key to the species of Potamogeton

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Potamogetonaceae

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Potamogetonaceae (including Ruppiaceae)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Conn, B.J. (1994). Potamogetonaceae (including Ruppiaceae). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves petiolate, distal leaves emergent and floating, dissimilar to basal submerged leaves
Leaves sessile and ± similar, all submerged
Floating leaves often ± translucent, membranous, with conspicuous secondary veins
Floating leaves opaque, ± leathery, with inconspicuous or not visible secondary veins

Floating leaves ovate to elliptic, 4–8 cm long, 3–5.5 cm wide, with more than 20 veins; inflorescence with more than 20 flowers; infructescence (excluding the non-fruiting part of axis) more than 3 cm long

Floating leaves lanceolate to ovate, rarely elliptic, 0.8–5 cm long, 1–3.5 cm wide, with less than 20 veins; inflorescence usually with fewer than 20 flowers; infructescence (excluding the non-fruiting part of axis) less than 3 cm long
Floating leaves lanceolate to ovate, more than 1.5 cm wide, with more than 10 veins
Floating leaves ellpitic to ovate, less than 1.5 cm wide, often with less than 10 veins
Leaves not clasping branch; base ± acute to rounded, not cordate
Leaves basally clasping branch; base cordate
Leaf margin entire, flat; leaf surface with numerous, fine longitudinal secondary veins, cross-connecting veins absent

Leaf margin serrulate and usually undulate to strongly crisped; leaf surface without numerous, fine longitudinal secondary veins, midrib and marginal longitudinal veins connected by well-spaced spreading veins
Leaf apex acute to mucronate; principal veins 3 (rarely 5)
Leaf apex rounded to obtuse; principal veins 5 (rarely 3)
